(1 comment)
Are you working with @Andrew to figure out how we keep this up to date?  Ideally the "srcrev bump" script would refresh the JSON as necessary.
Not yet, but happy to do that. I'm not familiar with the "srcrev bump" script, is that https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc-tools/blob/master/openbmc-autobump/openbmc-autobump.py?

Yes, that's what's run in a cron job to update all the .bb and .inc files that point to a openbmc/openbmc repo. Generating https://gerrit.openbmc.org/q/topic:%22autobump%22.
Updating a json file would def be something new for it.

Ok great, thanks for the confirmation.

I'm not personally familiar with that tool but I am comfortable with python. I'm happy to try to update the autobump tool to handle an npm-shrinkwrap.json file here, but would like to make sure that everyone is comfortable with the direction of this change before I spend time trying to write automation around it.
I'm in full support of this, so long as the logic gets added to the autobump script to keep these up to date automatically.
I believe this is now ready for review at https://gerrit.openbmc.org/c/openbmc/openbmc-tools/+/72499 and I've updated both changes to use the "webui-vue-offline" topic.
This is now ready for review.

Should these stay in the main recipe?   I'm not really seeing why they moved.  Does it help with automation?

webui-vue license should be Apache-2.0 only, the sub licenses should be other things, right?

I was torn on licenses. The output of devtool/recipetool puts everything in one file, but it somewhat takes over the recipe file. Moving it out felt cleaner, though I'm not even sure how automation would work here yet.

I don't know enough to answer the license question, this line was generated by devtool/recipetool.
ACK.
We still have no answer on licenses, what's the best path forward here?

I've removed the license information as it wasn't present in the original recipe. I do believe we should be including this information somehow, anyone generating an SBOM via Yocto would need this information, but they're not getting that now anyways.
Would inheriting npm-native instead solve this?  I see a lot of variables below (like NPM_ARCH) that I think just amount to "use a native recipe"
Ah I hadn't realized you could just inherit npm-native, but yes, that makes more sense here. I can look into that.

I've explored the idea of doing a native recipe, it does require some more changes, for instance switching from:

RDEPENDS:${PN}-webui = "webui-vue"

to:

DEPENDS:${PN}-webui = "webui-vue-native"

It also winds up not really making much of a difference in the recipe itself, we avoid the RDEPENDS:remove = "nodejs" but the NPM_ARCH setting still is needed, unless we push a patch upstream to add something like the following to npm.bbclass:

NPM_ARCH:class-native = "${@map_nodejs_arch(d.getVar("HOST_ARCH"), d)}"

If you're still more interested in this style I can get a change pushed up here.

I think -native is more technically correct, even if it's the same amount of config.

https://git.openembedded.org/openembedded-core/tree/meta/classes/npm.bbclass?h=thud#n24

That line sets NPM_ARCH based on TARGET_ARCH

And the native.bbclass sets TARGET_ARCH to HOST_ARCH

https://git.openembedded.org/openembedded-core/tree/meta/classes/native.bbclass?h=thud#n22

What I'm looking at should've worked for you if you inherited the native stuff correctly.  Oh well, probably not worth the effort to save a single line of recipe.
I should clarify, not worth the effort to debug.  I still think native is more correct for this inherit.

After some further exploring it appears that a "-native" package cannot actually deploy anything to the Target's rootfs, which unfortunately means this recipe may need to keep some of these rather silly workarounds. Marking this as resolved for now, but open to changes if someone else has any ideas!

I never really understood why one would want to do this instead of 

do_install::prepend

I'm not sure which one is better, I'm more curious why you went with addtask here.

I did it this way because I had thought this was more of a do_compile task than a do_install task, but do_compile is written in python and it didn't really make sense to try and wrap this code into python to append it.
I'm not sure I realized that the appends/prepends had to be in the same language.  That makes sense.

I believe the failure on zaius is not related to this change.

https://jenkins.openbmc.org/job/ci-openbmc/23726/distro=ubuntu,label=docker-builder,target=zaius/console
Next time, please retrigger in Jenkins then (I did this now).  We still need a "+1 Verified" before we merge commits.

I'm not sure where the -m64 is coming from but it's causing this commit to fail to build on ppc64le boxes (I wonder if we'll have similar issues on ARM based servers?).


How does one retrigger Jenkins?
Is this in CI?

Yes, we run additional CI against these commits on our servers. For example, when you see this comment on openbmc/openbmc commits:

"IBM Simulation CI: p10bmc simulation tests passed"

That's us rebuilding the commits with some host firmware and testing in our simulation. But all of our build machines are ppc64le based servers.

Can you retry? I got access to an Ampere server and found a very silly error (HOST_ARCH != BUILD_ARCH), though I suspect this may still fail, I'm still exploring an issue with the deasync package on ARM64, it works fine on x86_64 due to pre-built binaries.

Digging in a bit more I see some ppc64le-specific changes to nodejs, I've never used a ppc64le machine so I'm not sure if this is correct, but this might explain where -m64 is coming from?

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-openembedded/meta-oe/recipes-devtools/nodejs/nodejs_20.11.1.bb#L37

https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/master/meta-openembedded/meta-oe/recipes-devtools/nodejs/nodejs/0001-ppc64-Do-not-use-mminimal-toc-with-clang.patch

Though I'm also not sure if we're using clang or gcc here.

Yeah, weird that patch is there, but we still see the -m64. I manually cherry picked this latest commit onto our ppc64le machine and we're still seeing the same issue:

```
195 error gyp info using node@20.11.1 | linux | ppc64
...
195 error <string>:25: SyntaxWarning: invalid escape sequence '\s'
195 error gyp info spawn make
195 error gyp info spawn args [ 'BUILDTYPE=Release', '-C', 'build' ]
195 error arm-openbmc-linux-gnueabi-g++: error: unrecognized command-line option '-m64'
195 error arm-openbmc-linux-gnueabi-g++: error: unrecognized command-line option '-mminimal-toc'
195 error make: *** [deasync.target.mk:104: Release/obj.target/deasync/src/deasync.o] Error 1
195 error gyp ERR! build error
195 error gyp ERR! stack Error: `make` failed with exit code: 2
```

I'm not really sure how to resolve this without being able to explore on a ppc64le machine and that's not something I have access to. I have successfully built this on x86_64 and arm64. Is there any way to get me temporary access to a ppc64le machine? Or is it possible for me to retrigger IBM CI?

I managed to get this to build on my ppc64le with the following:

First I added this from the old recipe since the fail seemed compiler option related and it worked there:
```
+export CXX = "${BUILD_CXX}"
+export CC = "${BUILD_CC}"
+export CFLAGS = "${BUILD_CFLAGS}"
+export CPPFLAGS = "${BUILD_CPPFLAGS}"
+export CXXFLAGS = "${BUILD_CXXFLAGS}"
```

That got further but I got a different compile related error this time. Some grepping in the code found this added in a few other recipes:

```
+DEBUG_PREFIX_MAP:remove = "-fcanon-prefix-map"
```

With both of these added to webui-vue_git.bb, all built fine.
Done
We could SRC_URI:append this one so that you don't have the concerns with the parsing of the SRC_URI in the auto-update scripts?
My concern is this is an implicit, external-to-yocto dependency that isn't clear. Let me rework this with a comment explaining why to help avoid future surprises.
Done

Why did we change the PV?  Seems like we went backwards from 1.0 to 0.1.0, which isn't ideal.

I see that the "shrinkwrap" file used 0.1.0.  I wonder if we should fix this in webui-vue to set the version to 1.0?  It probably doesn't matter but generally you don't want the PV to go backwards because you potentially break RPM/IPK based installs.

That was autogenerated by devtool and I forgot to check. I can manually update it here to 1.0, I don't think this will cause problems even if https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/master/package.json#L3 is not updated & package-lock.json regenerated.
Done
This should ideally be fixed in webui-vue.  If they're going to call them "development dependencies" they should be that...

Maybe? I'm not much of a Vue expert, but it looked like some of the dependencies listed under devDependencies are required to build webui-vue, but not necessarily packaged in the bundle and deployed to the target. Given that this is closer to a -native recipe (but cannot be since -native recipes do not produce packages) this seemed acceptable to me, though would love for someone more familiar with Vue to weigh in here!

It was explained to me, that build tools are devDependencies, searching the internet seems to back that up. 

https://stackoverflow.com/questions/19339227/bower-and-devdependencies-vs-dependencies/19341028#19341028
 "devDependencies are used for tasks like testing, building, and local development."
https://www.dhiwise.com/post/package-management-devdependencies-vs-dependencies

https://frontendinterviewquestions.medium.com/difference-between-dependency-and-devdependency-2e8812b3f838
Do we know the "why"?

Essentially this is a -native recipe, but -native recipes cannot package/deploy to the rootfs (at least as far as I am aware). The npm.bbclass is really designed more for an npm package to run on the target, we're misusing it a bit to take advantage of it's do_fetch behavior for offline builds.
Ok... I guess I don't really understand the distinction.  It's all just JS code.  We're not actually "compiling" anything for use in the device or the [remote] client.

Unfortunately we are compiling, at least one of the dependencies (deasync, a dependency of vue-jest, https://github.com/openbmc/webui-vue/blob/master/package-lock.json#L23668) is a native package (see https://www.npmjs.com/package/deasync). This was the cause of the issues on ppc64le.

Comments in the original recipe indicate there is at least one other compiled component as well (https://github.com/openbmc/openbmc/blob/45ec794dad7661d4843151153e48327c02114de0/meta-phosphor/recipes-phosphor/webui/webui-vue_git.bb#L5).
Ack.
Any reason to not do this as a `do_compile:append`?
The do_compile task is python, it is not possible to append bash to python without a SyntaxError. This function is not complex enough to require python, so it made more sense to add a new task.

Got it.  This is a flaw in the npm.bbclass.  `do_compile` is a shell-style function everywhere except in npm.bbclass.  They probably should have added a redirect to call python instead.

I don't think you need to change it.  I'm slightly worried about this not showing up in the sstate cache correctly.  I guess we can cross that bridge when we get to it though.
Is there any harm in leaving the existing `do_install` and use a `do_install:append` for these bits?

The existing `do_install` task is intended to copy libraries/binaries, not javascript bundles. This makes sense for the intended purpose of npm.bbclass, but not for the way we are using it to simply deploy a javascript bundle to the target.
But do we have any libraries and binaries?

No, not in the sense of something running on the target. The output of webui-vue's build is a javascript bundle, intended to be served by an http server (bmcweb in our case). There are no libraries or binaries that should be included in the rootfs. Notably even if we did install libraries or binaries on the target we're explicitly not installing nodejs because it is unnecessary for webui-vue to function.
Don't we still want this RDEPENDS on bmcweb?
Yup! Fixed.
